attachments.extracted_content:
I’m writing to show you why I believe our systems emerge from our foundational beliefs and mindsets—about what the world is and what humans are. Like a dog that won't cross an electric fence, we are limited by our deepest assumptions, many of which are historically ingrained. The problem is that we have lost a way of relating to the world that honors quality and meaning over mere materiality, and I want to show you why reconnecting with that sense of depth helps us truly come alive. By coming alive and reconnecting with this lost way of seeing, we can build new kinds of systems that honor people as ends in themselves, not just means for achieving “impact,” “funding,” or “goals.”
Below, I’m going to walk you through:
Why emergent approaches matter more than rigid systems
Why our present mindset of “winners take all” and mastery is flawed
How honoring relationships, depth, and meaning (vs. breadth and metrics) can heal burnout
Why I think we can form a better foundation for Bloom.pm by coming alive first, then building systems
I’ll share the personal reflections, doubts, and inspirations that led me here. Then, I’ll remind you, in the end, what I told you.

Tell Them
Core Hypothesis: Systems Emerge From Our Foundational Beliefs
The suspicions I've been having about "winners take all" and that we can't take down the master's house with the master's tools are becoming clearer and clearer to me. I want to ensure that our work honors the non-instrumental nature of treating people as ends, not means to SDGs or impact, or stories to tell our donors. It's by doing the right things for the right reasons that we can be successful as human beings first, facing ourselves in the mirror. Honor and dignity are worth more than continued funding from donors who don't trust us to treat us well.
I am convinced that we need emergent approaches—good people and trust that they will do beautiful things—not good systems we attempt to shape people through. We are kind of limited by our foundational beliefs and understandings. Historically, these beliefs have led us to live in a way that is instrumental and transactional. We lost a different way we once had of seeing the world—one related to quality, to a sense of meaning, not just materiality.

Why Emergent Approaches Over Rigid Systems?
Even the idea that we can create systems of digital tools that scale and create an impact that is "out of our hands" is somehow missing something important. Our care and our connection are essential. We need to ensure that we are crafting something meaningful and beautiful—a system that honors the maker and the person using it, preserving their insight. There's something about relationship that we've been alienated from. We text instead of calling, we want to "blast" an email to thousands, and have systems with drop-offs at every stage instead of leaning into the connection and knowledge that grows from our spheres and through them to their spheres.
Through our connection with mentors, we can transmit these new ways of seeing and lived values—not as a list, but as a lived experience. This is how we can trust that they get it. We will know because we will see and feel it in our interactions with them. The idea that we can give a feedback form or an assessment and get answers from our mentors is only half right. They will only be able to share what they see with the eye of rationality. We need to see them with the eye of quality—the eye of Goodness, Truth, and Beauty—the eye that knows these things.

Critique of the “Winners Take All” Mindset
Developing skills and knowledge at the edge of our growth in the face of challenges means we need to be sincere about what we know and what we don't know, what we can do and what we can't. I believe that rushing into things because there is funding is a horrible reason to do something. What if we can get funding so people can know themselves, the world, and access what their hearts are calling them towards?
What if funding allowed us to go deeper, work with fewer, and support them as they worked it out, rather than pushing funding, expenditures, and movement that may be adding friction and doing a bunch of wrong things that'll need to be undone? With so much friction, we can certainly burn people out, as we've seen on our own teams. What are we really doing?

Relationships, Depth, and Healing Burnout
Then, we can have scalable systems where those people can impact others, rather than thinking about scale in breadth—showing how many people have jobs or planted trees. We need to get more comfortable with depth: how many people are having meaningful moments, finding their gifts, and sharing them in gratitude, making a more sincere, honest, and beautiful change versus one which has "good impact." Impact—the sound of a heavy book hitting the floor or an asteroid on the earth—reminds me of "fail fast and break things" and disruptive technologies. We don't need to be disruptive in these days; things are disruptive enough. We need to be a source of healing.
Why do we talk about wellbeing and stress? What if we aligned ourselves more humbly, took on projects that gave us deep connection, and built real community by helping everyone slow down enough to have community? We can move fast later when fast is what wants to happen. I know this sounds idealistic, and I know you worry about the business failing, and that's okay. I sort of think that business might need to go.

Foundational Beliefs and Historical Context
I don't know if you believe, as I do, that good things live and true things find their homes. If we don't focus on what we "can do to keep going" and truly focus on the problem that moves us and what brings us to life sincerely, if we are "eating our own dogfood," I think we'll find something. It might be small—who knows, maybe a team of two or three for a while—although I don't think that's so bad.
What if we found ways to help Bloom be a business we "want to do" rather than "have to do"? Perhaps we need to find other jobs to give us time to build the real thing we want to share with the world. Maybe we need time to reflect and can work like Einstein did at some desk job somewhere so we can think. Maybe our children happening, our contracts dwindling, isn't the time to rush. Maybe these are signs (if you believe in those things—perhaps you'd prefer signals) that we should slow down and think deeper. It's what I've been doing.

Personal Reflections: Coming Alive
I've been thinking about our time in Turkey and the idea of coming alive that was starting to come into resolution for me there. The ideas that there was something weird about helping people have goals for social change and getting them to take on the "habits and best practices to help them be most effective"—it's possible that I'm wrong, yet I think it's clearer than ever to me that this is not something I'm willing to subjugate. Initially, I thought I could draw on the "depth" of things, and the systems would help scale out to the "breadths" of things—that wellbeing and welldoing were possible to bring together in a harmonious balance.
Externally, that may be what people see when they witness someone like my friend Dug Song build businesses while being a family man, not leaving Detroit for Silicon Valley, and still skateboarding while building a business that sells for 2.x billion dollars. I think that this is not an accident and that it was not a set of systems that he took on or books he read. The idea of "habits of success" is so instrumental to me. If you think about it, you will use your will to compel your mind and body into specific patterns of behavior to achieve a goal. Your mind and body have become instruments for this goal. Is the goal worth it? Why do you think there's burnout, alienation, and why do you think even in the social sector there are bad actors who believe that the ends justify the means?

Relationality, Love, and Meaning as Ends
It's taken me a long time to accept the lessons I was given when I was younger, inspired by Father Greg Boyle. When they asked his intentions for doing his social enterprise, he didn't give some SDG that needed to be addressed or some "God told me to do it" nonsense. He said because they were his friends. Relationality, closeness, love, connection, and care—these are all ends, reasons to do things that no one should have to justify and might be impossible to justify because they are not perceived by the eye of rationality. They are perceived by the eye that knows what goodness is, what truth is, and what beauty is. That eye is the one that I would like to cultivate.
The Nietzsche quote, "He who has a strong enough why can overcome any how," guides me here. People who love have climbed mountains—"there ain't no mountain high enough," "there ain't no ocean vast enough"—to keep them away from the beauty they want to do. This is a real reason, a source of persistence, vitality, and passion to knock on a thousand doors until one opens. This is why they'll leave our heart-based aliveness-focused program and join Y Combinator to get what they need financially or figure something totally new and unexpected out.
I'm finally able to see why I care so much about community, the upside-down pyramid, starting with why, character strengths, and coming alive. It's not about some materialist interpretation of mindfulness-based stress reduction for people to better manage their emotions to do the nonsense they have committed to doing. It's about coming to view emotions as messengers, to look through them into the place they touch your heart. Why do we feel sad when we see animals going extinct? What about that is meaningful for us that's being lost? Think about it, feel into it, see what echoes within you. Those emotions are treasures, and we are constantly being played by a masterful orchestra.

Emotions as Messengers of Meaning
Each tense emotion tells us something about a blocked source of meaning. Each positive emotion is a gift to enjoy, persist, and sink into what we're doing without being attached. Contentedness is not an emotion; it's a state. I believe these states are profoundly important to the idea of why we should be doing things and can be found when we tap into our sources of meaning, come alive, and heed their calls with small, bold actions. Similar to the zone described by the flow state, where our skills are at the edge of our capacity and the challenge we're at, we can gradually find the next emerging way of being by responding to the constant flow of calls.

Where the Current System Falls Short
This means trust, implies process, and moves people, businesses, projects, and more from a system of semi-static parts to an alive, organic whole that cannot be segmented, assessed with forms, analyzed, projected into the future, and planned. It's the reality that it's hubris to think otherwise. It's part of the insanity about why the iNGOs are more than happy to give us jobs, yet are silent when it comes to keeping us alive (Palestinians and Lebanese). We saw how let down the people who can see this hypocrisy felt. It's so true though—the goals, the SDGs, the plans—these things are dead on arrival. The reality of being responsive, being real, being caring, being human and humane is lost to the organizations focused on the attainment of something.
I know this all probably sounds crazy. In fact, I'm confident that since you've known me long enough, you might accept it a bit more. Yet for me, it took a while to finally deconstruct a few things, starting with Aristotle and the idea of classification. Aristotle’s metaphysics focus on cause-and-effect relationships (final cause, material cause) percolate like water through the grounds of Western culture and get amplified by the mechanistic thinking of the Scientific Revolution (Descartes, Newton). It's just a brain watching a world of parts interact—sort of system thinking, Hobbes. Oh crap, Christians are killing each other; we're totally horrible, and we need a rational government to put things in order. Systems should be what we follow, not people. Enlightenment off with his headism, individualist pieces that can reason best for themselves, laden with democratic American ideas like "let's pick happiness as a teleological conclusion," etc.

Historical Roots and a Lost Way of Seeing
We live in a soulless world of rational objects, bodies needing food, cause-effect transactions in a swirl of beautiful elegance making a souffle out of anthropology, biology, chemistry, physics, and the mathematics that Galileo said is the perfect way to describe the world. It can all be displayed as a nice little infographic—the world is made of markets transacting materiality. The hard problem of consciousness is irrelevant when we have people dying of malaria, and we go fix that because death is bad. What about not living at all, not coming alive, becoming a machine, giving up your ability to sense meaning and connect to true purpose for some fear-based worry your philosophical forefathers (that most have no idea about or understand the impact of the history of ideas) had?
We're here because of someone else's war, freaking people out. Our systems destroy the planet due to seeing humans as human resources for a machine that's efficiently transforming materiality into material to satisfy the needs and desires of humans. If there aren't enough desires to create enough demand to necessitate the improvement of the systems and optimization to achieve goals more efficiently, because hey, what rational person wouldn't want cheaper tomatoes? Who cares if we breed them to be transported across the ocean and have no idea what that does to the flavor, let alone nutritional profile?

It’s About Our Way of Seeing, Not Just Different Goals
We must use these fear-based epistemologies and ontologies that see the world full of nasty, brutish people who will die shortly unless we use our reason to align with the reason of the natural world, to break it up into little pieces and use it to our favor. And BTW, the people who think like this are more likely to be skiing in the Alps and owning businesses than running them. Also, their kids don't go to public schools and get graded like screws and meat of varying quality. By the way, I'm more of a B/B+ sort of person than a Grade A, so here, doing this thinking is a bit out of my weight class. Yet I digress, and I try anyway to help you see, feel, and understand this foundational thing.
It's NOT about the wrong goals, profit or SDGs. It's not even about the systems leveraging personal and professional growth to help transform the economic system into one that's better for people and the planet. No, it's about the way of seeing and understanding what a person is, what the world is, and the systems that emerge from that understanding.

Reconnecting With Meaning for New Systems to Emerge
Our neoliberal order is sort of a beautiful system that is hard to argue with. Market efficiency sort of works, as does reductionist science as we break atoms further down into their core. We can understand the material and superficial world and can move things, energy, resources, and food—all commodities—which the markets manage, valuing perfectly well. The problem is there is no reason for this elegant dance of a billion buy-sell decisions mostly run by machines. There is only short-sighted efficiency of materiality.
I've tried not to say God in this run-on paragraph. Yet it's a bit hard not to, so how about you look at your favorite person, a loved one, and convince yourself they are a "user" of Instagram, a customer of Zara, or a citizen of a country—little pinballs bouncing around in the systems of goals and accomplishments of others. What about your feeling of love? That's some oxytocin and some serotonin floating around a bloodstream in a body that wants to keep its bodily integrity intact so that it can propagate itself and not die. You cannot learn Darwin's theory and believe it without hurting your soul a little bit. There are people who die for beauty—don't you know? There are things that matter more than life itself. You know this; you may have even felt this if you're lucky. Yet we have no way in our modern mindset to understand it, where we can place it, what power this is that is ultimately lost.
These things have been bugging me for a long time. I started in education, realizing the issue with the control systems being forced on children—full of aliveness and dreams, shaping them into consumers and workers. I saw the post-WWII economic system require us to win the war of ideas and ensure that capitalism produces power and material success, and we did it at our own expense. Sure, this is all fine, said typing on a MacBook Pro made by a capitalist company with $216 billion in cash reserves, benefiting from the international trade that brings me coffee from Ethiopia to my door and markets that pressure countries to fight on my behalf so everything is affordable and safe.
Yet I think it doesn't have to be revolutionary. I think the simple act of finding that part of us that can see and feel what beauty and goodness are and asking it what it needs to shine and doing that—a little each day. Weirdly enough, for me, it's writing you this long letter. I was going to use AI to help clean it up and summarize and make it all polished, yet somehow I think that goes against my point here. We need to see each other, even our messy selves. This is from my heart to yours. I'm writing this with you, Dara, and you, Munir, in mind.
It's been a long struggle for me, starting before 2022 in Turkey—where I've felt off, yet I acquiesced, allowing my doubt in my own feelings to fester. I thought maybe he's right. Maybe we can keep doing/building this way. Maybe I'm wrong. Maybe there's a productive tension. I mentioned these ideas of coming alive in the retreat, although I think I didn't realize at the time that that's the foundational thing I want to do—the upside-down pyramid, self-efficacy, character strengths, notes journal, breakout rooms, one-on-ones, the 1% better journey were about that. Goals can come not from a dream of a desired future state, but they can emerge from becoming the kind of person who achieves that goal. Don't plan to run a marathon; become a runner. We've talked about these.
Yet more foundationally, this clarity shows me the kinds of things to focus on: we should measure at the end of the day and attend to our sources of meaning at the start. The story of self and the story of the world can and must be discovered and grown so we can allow our qualitative witnessing to see, echo, resonate with, and inspire knowledge and action. Togetherness matters, being a mirror matters, finding emotions is precious, discerning between emotions and states matters, goals can be had, yet ways of being we admire are what we must engender and practice. We can go slow, be gentle with ourselves, and be successful once we start on the path to self-knowledge and alignment with values, perception, and enaction.
I think sometimes you must think that I'm crazy, and perhaps I am. Although I'm working on developing my ideas, gathering stories (microfinance was beautiful, right? Amu Yunus got a Nobel Prize, cool? Well, we're seeing the fruits of not foundationally changing the perception of what finance is, what money is, what it serves. What a human is with a spate of suicides as a result of not being able to pay the petty sum back and being hounded by people who are achieving "targets"—targets, pretty grim).
I'm working on developing this into a clearer vision of what I think my work in "social impact" can be, what I think the problems are of burnout and lack of wellbeing. And no, it's not only because we don't have money for paid holidays; there's something burning about using yourself for something that is not yourself. We can cultivate gardens of conditions—we must treat people as ends and get close. Relationships matter, commitment matters, connection matters. Scale can happen in a beautiful and authentic way, probably not in the way we plan, where we draw hockey stick charts and hope and hope again.
I sometimes think perhaps I've been saved from success because I'm not sure I would have had the time, perspective, and frustration, quite frankly, to see as I do. Am I just "sourgraping" this whole thing? I don't think so. I think indigenous economics—talking about cyclical time (not linear) thinking, seven generations (not retiring when I'm 40), relationships with a world of meaning (not humans and nature as resources to extract)—are similar. Yet indigenous economics stays small and sort of implies we must take their principles and ways of doing things rather than discovering them ourselves in our own indigeneity—our Lebanese indigenous economics—emerging from systems built by people who have reintegrated both eyes, seeing with reason and logic and the eyes of meaning and quality. Being confident enough to know we need to be wary of too much planning in an era of collapse. We need to live in a way that when the bombs drop or the seas start rising, we are confident we did what we were made to do and were successful at every step of the way, no matter if we arrived wherever we thought we might or not.

Remind Them of What We Told Them
So there you have it. I’ve told you about:
How our systems emerge from deep-seated beliefs and mindsets
Why emergent approaches and depth of relationship matter more than quick, scalable fixes
How transactional and instrumental thinking leads to burnout, while real connection can heal and help us come alive
Why the historical context of our beliefs has stripped us of a sense of meaning and how reconnecting with that meaning might guide us forward
I hope this short essay made some sense. I wanted to share this to see if you have feedback, what gaps were in my logic. I think this is what I want to do next for work: to operationalize this process of first recognizing the perceptual faculty that we're being gaslit not to identify (artists usually are pretty clear about this, good ones at least). That faculty can see things and know things that are both reliable and true—just as reason can see and we can deduce truth, we can do that with quality as well.
By finding that and living it more in our lives, we come alive, and by coming alive we bring energy and goodness, building capacity, skills, relationships, knowledge, stories of self, stories of world—essentially forging a new foundation for new systems to emerge. We all need to awaken the artist within us to help us weave a more beautiful story that is just as true, and perhaps more true, to undo the fragility of systems and unearth the beauty and humility of emergence.
I don't think I intend to "get by" anymore with my work. I have to share what I know, or I shrivel up and help no one. I remember being asked in 2016 to make an entrepreneurship program, and I thought it was silly to have everyone do the same assignments. I thought it would be cool to direct people to the things they needed with technology. Today, I'm going back again and having another one of those moments where I can't do the same thing anymore. I need to do something different, something beautiful, and I'd love to do it with you—if you're in with me :)

Warm regards,
[Your Name]

Okay, so we're going to be writing an essay with our voice because one of my skills and competencies and something that I pride myself in is my ability to follow a thread clearly and coherently and articulated, and this content must be mine and come from my heart and not be external and also it must be connected to all realities. It's my intention that this becomes a snapshot of my thinking about the truths that I've discovered in my life and the realities they imply towards a good life and how that impacts the sense of speed, rush, fear, otherness, alienation, and impending disaster with the climate, the wars the mistrust of our neighbors and the lack of time and space and knowledge of what to do with ourselves. I'm indebted to my mom who shared with me in October of 2011 their aid prayer from Mecca, and in that prayer there was a talk and in that talk the speaker, shared the idea that God is beautiful, and he loves that which is beautiful and in that time, I was very hurt and unable to accept all of the tradition that I had been raised with because it was getting in the way of me trusting my heart, and that tension the reality that this person I respected and admired was some one that my heart honestly could lean towards and brought me aliveness was fighting with the textual reality of the lack of an articulated Islam or Christianity that I could check some box in an accounting system with the god and with my family to say that this woman is a Muslim and therefore I am allowed to have these feelings. rather than the fear, hope, trepidation, openness, wonder anticipation heart opening heart racing, mind spinning possibility, of accepting love.  I remember laying down on the ground outside and she asked me, do you love me? and rather than taking a moment to take a deep breath to look inside of my heart, and to say the truth of what I found, I deflected. I asked for literalism.  I asked how do you define love? There are places within us that know love that can distinguish love from lust and in my confusion and desire to be confused to avoid the pain and the stress and the fear of confronting my family and confronting the check box guard and religion that I had invented that wasn't the true way of interpreting are the only way I deflected and created confusion in my life and compounded that confusion for years and years I allowed myself in that confusion to create a shadow and to have the part of me that was alive to live in that shadow. I nook out of the house in the dark to be able to be with the parts of me that were actually alive and I lived like a zombie, having not slept and like a zombie because in the day I was living waiting for the night distant from my heart, distant from the thing that knows the truths of the world and the truths within myself. and in October 2011 I was given one of the keys of a trifecta that allowed me to open my heart and to connect reintegrate with my emotions, with my feelings, with my perception of beauty, with my sense of meaning and sense of self, and ultimately, at long last, the realizations that beauty is the splendor of truth. and beauty is that which draws you into love, and that the perception and recognition of beauty is a part of a faculty that is inextricable from that perception and that reality.  This faculty within us that sees beauty is the place where we can answer the questions of what is true and the confusions that we might have about what is actually good How should we live? What is real? My background as someone who loves science and technology and philosophy and rationalizations.  I think connects to this desire for control and this lack of engaging with the fear and the reality of the bird that when it wakes up and opens its eyes and sees its hungry children, and leaves its nest in fear and hope, seeking the worms, the seeds, the sustenance and the awe in the wonder and the gratitude and the aliveness at finding it. This way of seeing the world and living in the world requires both eyes, we do have a rational faculty We can think ahead to plant seeds now to organize our land, to let land rest after understanding soil depletion so that we can have a better harvest next year and I've realized that this love of planning and stability along with my rejection of the tradition that was brought to me that was teaching me how to open the eye of the heart. limited me from being able to explore in an open way, and the only way that's real on the tight rope of life to keep my eyes focused on beauty and to walk without looking down knowing and not knowing that the next step is going to land and that will be okay and that will make it. because the rope is invisible to the tight rope walker. It's just sensed, just like the worm is invisible to the bird. and in the muslin tradition were given many promises of what happens to those who trust and have god consciousness that these are those that are successful.  And these beliefs I think must be taken gradually, step by step. You take one step, that proves the rope is there, you leave one morning, you find the worms, but winter comes, things change, the wind blows, and the rope moves ever so slightly. and so I believe that it's not that we must avoid planning planting the seeds and using our mind, but that we need as a society to traverse this canyon. We are in a place where our stasis is destructive, our not changing is damaging, and I believe the roots of why staying the same is damaging is connected to the roots that have alienated us from this perception of beauty and truth and goodness, and even trusting that this means something that it's not an emotion only that it may have states ways that are uplifting inspire us.  You watch a movie about Nelson Mandela and you leave uplifted the sense of possibility and hope and maybe you think to yourself, how can I be a little more like that? And so the first thing that happened to me after my partner broke up with me because I could not face the fear. of the reality that was being that was beckoning the reality of I love this person and I don't know what to do. I'm young I don't know my faith.  I don't know myself. I don't know what love actually means. that love is the splendor of truth and that beauty and truth and love come together and that if I wanted to know God and how to live I have to read all three books the book of revelation, the book of inner insight and looking within our feelings, our thoughts, even our negative ruminations, and the book of the outer world the beauty of a river flowing down a mountain and a waterfall, and fish below in a clear pond eating the bugs on the river and then if you follow that river as it passes through human civilization on the other side, you look again into the water, and you find ugliness, a weird slimy color, a film on the top of the water potentially dead fish, a bad smell it repulses you. and why is that the case? How is this also true and how is that assign?  These signs of repulsion could have prevented us from continuing down this path the they would say the smell of London in the 1800s the squalor the tight neighborhoods with sewage flowing down the middle and Jack the Ripper and the pollution bellowing into the air and kids coming home in the morning after working at night shift in a factory and injuries and I'm sure people knew this wasn't beautiful. yet it helped increase the sense of control because there was a a power to it that could be grown resources accumulating into the hands of the owners allowing more allocating according to their desires and whims, unchecked and unpurified and unhe held up against the example of beauty and this alienation from the things that make life meaningful, require us to fill it with a hope that the future will be better. I don't feel so good right now, but I believe in this progress that we're making, this idea of progress links in deeply with this idea of how the reward system within us works. our sense of accomplishments and reward and the molecule dopamine that symbolizes it is not from achievement. It's not from making a goal and accomplishing it.  The reward comes from the expectation of a good, and so as long as we were able to tell ourselves in each other, this world might not be good to day, but to morrow it will be better when technology improves when we're able to extract more from less when we have to work less, this claim that, you know, we increase productivity and somehow work less and enjoy more is not what has happened at all. We've increased productivity and working hours, and at the same time we're reducing wages. This confusion about what is good, what do we want from life, this sense of mastery has been possible for only 200300 years and it was made possible from the primary disconnect from people with some their core faculty that is able to see and then the practice of implementing the seeing of beauty into a cycle of life that shows that you can take another step on that tight rope towards a more beautiful future and instead we went into a command and control into a cycle of allowing the things that think a we are able to control our situation and preserve our station and expand our domination and to manage people and the planet and the colonies and to do all of this in a way where we start having the science of productivity and the science of the polity and political science and we have this illusion of being able to get what we want without ever opening the eyes within us that can know what we actually want, and with only one eye, we can only see what we think we want, our needs, our fears, our expectations, and we try to address those, but it's it's a bottomless pit because the only thing that can really fill those is the eye that is able to see our true desires for love, beauty, connection, and the things that are truly satisfying.  And so what happens as we fall into lust or we fall into gluttony, or we fall into laziness, and we build escalators, and then when our bodies start falling apart, we go to the gym. And so understanding that dohamine is this reward molecule, I think is really important to see why we always imagine heaven as to morrow and that promise that things will be better, I think, kept people in a cage of anticipation and patience. of gritting our teeth kind of patience, but then, as we see in to day's world, we see that our uncontrolled, desire for control has expanded our unbeautiful ways of being into manipulating more of the world into ugliness into factories that fall on the people working to make our clothes and into promoting consumption just to be able to maintain the systems into this problematic situation that we find ourselves in that I think really is exemplified by this disconnect between this faculty that knows what is actually good and beautiful rather than the faculty that sees and wants for oneself, it's the faculty that sees and in that seeing can be satisfied in the connection and relating and and then we can talk very plainly about the rise of suicide. uh being one of the leading causes of death for young people, the beginning of suicides in preteens, which is unthinkable and it is kind of vague sense of anxiety they say that in the last 30 years the levels of anxiety have skyrocketed around the world, and we're coming to a place where I think we have to open that other eye. - Current approaches treat people as means to ends
- Systems built on control rather than emergence
- Burnout from disconnection from meaning
- SDGs and metrics as insufficient guides

## II. A Different Way of Seeing
- The heart's natural capacity to recognize beauty
- Beauty as a natural attractor of attention 
- Recognition vs implementation
- The role of presence in allowing recognition

- Systems emerge from our way of seeing
- The problem with "winners take all" mindset
- Speed vs natural unfolding
- Role of tension in revealing blocked meaning

- Starting with individual meaning/beauty
- Building emergent rather than controlling systems
- Using tension as growth signal
- Prioritization through meaning rather than metrics

- From acceleration to emergence
- Supporting natural unfolding vs forcing growth
- Working with tensions rather than goals
- Creating conditions for meaning to emerge

- Individual practice of presence
- Organizational transformation
- New metrics based on meaning
- Building communities of practice

input.title: The Crisis in Social Impact
input.content:
# The Crisis in Social Impact: When People Become Instruments

The crisis in social impact runs deeper than failed projects or inefficient programs. It stems from a fundamental misunderstanding of what humans are and what makes life meaningful. We see this play out tragically in examples like microcredit, where what began as a beautiful vision of helping people out of poverty transformed into a transactional relationship between lender and borrower. When people become instruments for achieving metrics, we shouldn't be surprised when this leads to tragic outcomes like the spate of suicides among borrowers who couldn't meet repayment targets.

This instrumentalization shows up everywhere in the social sector. Large iNGOs create programs to generate jobs and employ refugees, meeting EU and UN metrics, but remain silent when wars threaten those same people's lives. Why? Because their systems are built to count jobs, not honor human beings. The metrics become more real than the people they're meant to serve.

Even in our own work at Bloom, I've watched this tension play out. We built software to track tasks, create dashboards, monitor progress – all the things funders want to see. We tried to use the techniques of Facebook, Instagram, and Duolingo to "hook" people into good habits. But I've come to realize these techniques themselves are the problem. They're built on assumptions about humans that deny our capacity for meaning and reflection.

Think about Duolingo's streaks: You might maintain a perfect streak learning French without actually caring about French or being able to speak it. You're responding to the metric, not the meaning. This is what happens when we prioritize measurement over life – we get perfect streaks instead of real learning, job numbers instead of human flourishing, repayment rates instead of actual poverty reduction.

The problem isn't measurement itself. We could measure different things – moments of meaning people experience at work, the emergence of new capabilities, the quality of connections formed. But first we need to shift from seeing people as instruments for achieving goals to seeing them as sources of meaning and beauty waiting to emerge.

Instead of treating social impact like a machine where we input resources and extract metrics, what if we thought of it more like gardening? There's humility in planting seeds, amazement when the tomatoes appear, acceptance that some seasons yield more than others. Our goals could be like fruits – important to anticipate but not to force. The real work is in preparing the soil, understanding the conditions that allow life to flourish, and trusting in the natural unfolding of growth.

This requires a fundamental shift in how we approach social impact. Instead of starting with metrics and working backward, we need to start with meaning and let the right measures emerge. Instead of using "engagement techniques" to hook people into good habits, we need to create spaces where people can discover what naturally draws their attention. Instead of treating people as means to achieve SDGs or impact metrics, we need to honor them as ends in themselves.

The crisis isn't just that our current approach isn't working well enough – it's that it's working exactly as designed, treating humans as instruments rather than sources of meaning. To address this, we need more than better metrics or more efficient systems. We need a completely different way of seeing.

# The Crisis in Social Impact: From Factory Farms to Food Forests

Imagine two ways of growing food: A factory farm and a food forest. The factory farm operates on desperate arithmetic: this much fertilizer plus this much soil must equal this much yield and this much profit. Everything is monitored, measured, controlled. When anything goes wrong - a late frost, a new pest - the whole fragile system risks collapse. The farmer, despite all their planning and control, can still go bankrupt.

Now imagine a food forest: diverse, alive, resilient. Every plant, insect, and microorganism participates in countless feedback cycles too complex to measure. The system works not because someone controls it, but because everything in it is fully alive, being exactly what it is, contributing naturally to the whole.

This contrast captures the fundamental crisis in social impact work today. We're trying to run social change like a factory farm when it needs to be grown like a food forest. We see this everywhere:

Microcredit programs achieve perfect repayment rates while borrowers commit suicide. iNGOs create thousands of refugee jobs while remaining silent when wars threaten those same refugees' lives. Our metrics look beautiful on paper while the human spirit withers. We're getting exactly what we measure, but missing what matters most.

Even in our own work at Bloom, I've watched this pattern play out. We built systems to track tasks, create dashboards, monitor progress – trying to "optimize" human development like crop yields. We borrowed techniques from Facebook and Instagram to "hook" people into good habits, as if meaningful change could be manufactured like factory tomatoes.

The problem goes deeper than failed projects or inefficient programs. It stems from a fundamental desire for control and domination – even when that domination wears a beautiful mask. "We're planting trees! We're employing refugees! We're reducing CO2!" But if we're still forcing things to happen according to our predetermined metrics rather than allowing life to unfold naturally, we're still operating from domination, not aliveness.

Consider how bureaucracy and automation increasingly remove human judgment from human situations. When a starving person steals from a store, rigid policies demand banishment – no space for the beautiful moment where forgiveness and a job offer might transform two lives. When billions of people interact through automated systems, there's no room for human wisdom to emerge.

This isn't just ineffective – it's dangerous. Just as factory farming creates fragile systems dependent on artificial inputs, our metrics-driven approach to social impact creates programs that look good on paper but collapse under real-world complexity. We're optimizing for what we can measure while missing the immeasurable qualities that make life worth living.

The solution isn't better metrics. We could measure different things – moments of meaning people experience at work, instances of unexpected generosity, the quality of connections formed. But first we need to shift from seeing people as outputs to manage to sources of beauty waiting to emerge.

What if instead of trying to control outcomes, we focused on creating conditions where people can understand themselves, understand the world, and respond with what they think is best in every moment? What if instead of measuring success by predetermined metrics, we looked for signs of life: Are people experiencing moments of meaning at work? Are they living their values? Are beautiful, unexpected solutions emerging naturally?

This requires radical humility. # The Crisis in Social Impact: Lost Gardens, Lost Ways of Seeing

Imagine two ways of growing food: A factory farm and a food forest. The factory farm operates on desperate arithmetic: this much fertilizer plus this much soil must equal this much yield and this much profit. Everything is monitored, measured, controlled. The food forest, by contrast, is diverse, alive, resilient - every plant, insect, and microorganism participating in countless feedback cycles too complex to measure.

But why do we default to factory farming approaches, not just in agriculture but in social change? The answer lies in how we've come to see human nature. We've inherited a worldview - from Descartes through Hobbes to Darwin - that sees humans as essentially self-interested machines, biological computers trying to survive and reproduce, potentially at others' expense. From this view, emergence means chaos. Without control, we assume we'll get violence, not beauty.

This belief acts like an invisible electric fence - even when the power is off, we won't cross it. We say "I have to get ahead," "We have to defend ourselves," "We have to measure everything" as if these are laws of nature rather than choices emerging from fear. We've lost trust in our natural capacity to perceive and pursue what's beautiful and true.

We see this pattern everywhere in social impact work:
- Microcredit programs achieve perfect repayment rates while borrowers commit suicide
- iNGOs create thousands of refugee jobs while remaining silent when wars threaten those same refugees' lives
- Organizations hit their metrics while the human spirit withers

But this approach isn't just ineffective - it's based on a profound misunderstanding of human nature. People will literally die for meaning, beauty, and love. We have a natural capacity to recognize what's sacred, what's life-giving, what's true. The problem isn't that people need to be controlled - it's that we've lost touch with our ability to perceive and act from meaning.

This isn't about unleashing raw emotion or unconscious impulses. Many destructive patterns emerge from unexamined fears and wounds. Instead, it's about developing our capacity to look through emotions to what they point toward - our deepest sources of meaning and beauty. When we touch these, we enter a different state entirely - not a fleeting feeling but a recognition of something real and true.

What if instead of trying to control outcomes, we focused on creating conditions where people can access this natural capacity for recognition? What if instead of measuring success by predetermined metrics, we looked for signs of life: Are people experiencing moments of meaning at work? Are they living their values? Are beautiful, unexpected solutions emerging naturally?

This requires radically rethinking how we approach change. Like a gardener who knows they don't create the tomatoes - they just create conditions where tomatoes can grow - we need to shift from manufacturing impact to nurturing aliveness. The food forest isn't anxiously waiting for apples; even the decaying leaves in winter are a sign of life doing exactly what it should.

Every item on our to-do lists reveals this pattern: How many are "have to's" driven by fear and control? How many are "want to's" emerging from our recognition of what's beautiful and meaningful? Our organizations show the same divide: How much space do we make for the slower, qualitative perception that knows what's truly important?

This isn't just about better methods or metrics. It's about recovering our lost capacity to recognize and align with beauty. We need approaches that honor both our rational faculties and our ability to perceive meaning - that help us purify our fears and nurture our natural attraction to what's true and good.

The crisis in social impact isn't ultimately about failed projects or inefficient programs. It's about a way of seeing that has forgotten half of what it means to be human. To address this, we need more than better systems - we need to rediscover our natural capacity for recognizing and creating beauty.

input.content:
# The Crisis in Social Impact: Recovering Our Capacity to See

Years ago, I heard Father Greg Boyle explain why he worked with gang members. He didn't talk about metrics or impact or solving problems. He said simply: "They're my friends." Something clicked for me in that moment. I realized how much of my "social impact" work had been instrumental - doing things for my career, for metrics, for some future outcome - rather than being fully present to the humans in front of me.

This insight changed everything. I moved to Beirut and opened my home. Some of my dearest friends today were once refugees living on the streets, polishing shoes, running from police. This isn't a story about impact - it's about what becomes possible when we trust a different way of seeing.

I learned this lesson again when I met my wife. On paper, nothing added up. She didn't speak English, knew nothing about the Middle East, was planning to return to France. Friends these days make actual spreadsheets comparing potential partners. But something else spoke - quieter than desire, deeper than logic. Following this recognition was terrifying. Now I watch our baby grow, surprised and grateful at the beauty that unfolds when we ask not "what do I want?" but "what wants to happen?"

These personal stories point to a broader pattern playing out everywhere in social impact work. We've inherited approaches built on control and measurement rather than recognition and emergence. Like factory farms forcing maximum yield through artificial inputs, we try to manufacture impact through metrics and optimization. We see the results all around us:
- Rising anxiety and suicide rates showing our disconnect from self
- Increasing polarization showing our disconnect from each other
- Ecological collapse showing our disconnect from nature

But there's another way, more like growing a food forest than running a factory farm. I experienced this with a hackerspace I started in Michigan. Initially, I had rigid ideas: everything free, all decisions by consensus. But I learned to trust the people drawn to the space. They saw needs I couldn't see, evolved the model to include tiered pricing and democratic decision-making. Thirteen years later, All Hands Active still serves its community - not because I controlled it, but because I learned to let something beautiful emerge.

This isn't about abandoning metrics or rationality. It's about recovering our natural capacity to recognize what's true, beautiful, and good - without needing to analyze or justify it. We all have this faculty, this way of seeing that knows when something rings true. But we've been taught to distrust it, to rely instead on spreadsheets and impact measurements.

The cost is enormous. When we can't access this faculty for recognizing quality and meaning, we miss the very thing that makes life worth living. We can pursue all the elements of wellbeing - positive emotions, relationships, engagement, achievement - but they feel hollow when manufactured rather than emerging naturally from meaning.

What if instead of trying to optimize and control, we focused on creating conditions where beauty and meaning can naturally emerge? What if instead of measuring predetermined outcomes, we developed our capacity to recognize and respond to what life is calling for?

This isn't just about better methods or metrics. It's about recovering a lost way of seeing - one that could transform how we approach social change. To understand why this matters and how to move forward, we need to look more deeply at how we lost this capacity and what it takes to recover it.

# The Crisis in Social Impact: What We Measure vs What Matters

In 2006, Muhammad Yunus won the Nobel Peace Prize for pioneering microcredit - small loans that would lift millions out of poverty. The metrics were perfect: high repayment rates, growing reach, measurable income increases. By every standard measure, it was working. Yet by 2010, something disturbing emerged in Indian newspapers: a wave of suicides among borrowers. How could a program be simultaneously succeeding by every metric and failing so fundamentally at its human mission?

This pattern - of initiatives that succeed on paper while missing something essential - shows up everywhere in social impact work. Organizations hit their KPIs while their staff burn out. Refugee programs create thousands of jobs while remaining silent when those same refugees face existential threats. Environmental projects count trees planted while ecosystems collapse.

The easy response is to blame bad metrics - to say we're measuring the wrong things. But what if the problem goes deeper? What if it's not just about what we measure, but about our belief that measurement alone can guide us toward what matters?

I learned this lesson personally when I heard Father Greg Boyle explain why he worked with gang members. He didn't talk about recidivism rates or impact metrics. He said simply: "They're my friends." Something clicked for me. I realized how much of my "social impact" work had been instrumental - doing things for metrics, for my career, for some future outcome - rather than being fully present to the humans in front of me.

This isn't about abandoning metrics or rationality. That would be like saying because black and white photography misses color, we should stop taking pictures. Metrics aren't wrong - they're incomplete. They capture important patterns but miss essential qualities, like trying to understand a garden by measuring only height and yield.

Consider two ways of growing food: A factory farm and a food forest. The factory farm operates on pure metrics: this much fertilizer plus this much soil must equal this much yield. Everything is monitored, measured, controlled. The food forest, by contrast, is diverse, alive, resilient - every plant, insect, and microorganism participating in countless feedback cycles too complex to measure. Both produce food, but one creates fragile systems dependent on artificial inputs while the other builds lasting vitality.

I experienced this contrast directly when I started a hackerspace in Michigan. Initially, I had rigid ideas: everything free, all decisions by consensus - metrics for maximum accessibility and democracy. But something unexpected happened when I learned to trust the people drawn to the space. They saw needs I couldn't see, evolved the model to include tiered pricing and new governance. They made it less "perfect" by my original metrics but more alive, more sustainable. Thirteen years later, that space still serves its community - not because I controlled it, but because I learned to let something beautiful emerge.

This pattern shows up in our personal lives too. When I met my wife, nothing added up on paper. She didn't speak English, knew nothing about my culture, was planning to return to France. Friends these days make actual spreadsheets comparing potential partners. But something else spoke - quieter than desire, deeper than logic. Now I watch our baby grow, surprised and grateful at the beauty that unfolds when we ask not "what do I want?" but "what wants to happen?"

The most successful organizations aren't succeeding because they found perfect metrics. They're succeeding because they've learned to complement measurement with a deeper way of seeing - one that recognizes quality and meaning directly, without needing to quantify everything. They use metrics like a good gardener uses soil tests: as one tool among many, always in service of the living whole.

This capacity for recognizing quality isn't mystical or anti-rational. We all have it. It's what lets us know when something rings true, when a solution fits, when a community is thriving. But we've been taught to distrust it, to rely instead on spreadsheets and impact measurements. The cost is enormous - not just in failed programs and burnout, but in our diminished capacity to address the complex challenges we face.

Climate change, social polarization, rising mental health crises - these aren't problems we can optimize our way out of. They require a different way of seeing that can recognize patterns too complex to measure, that can sense what wants to emerge rather than forcing predetermined outcomes.

The crisis in social impact isn't ultimately about failed metrics. It's about a way of seeing that has forgotten half of what it means to be human. To understand why this matters and how to move forward, we need to look more deeply at how we lost this capacity and what it takes to recover it.

# The Great Forgetting: How We Lost Our Way of Seeing

When Galileo declared mathematics the language of the universe, he added an important caveat: this new science could measure quantity but not quality. Yet in our enthusiasm for the power of measurement, we forgot the second part of his insight. This forgetting reshaped how we see ourselves, nature, and purpose itself.

The story of how we lost touch with quality isn't just academic history - it shows up in our daily lives. Consider how we "grade" students: A through F, reducing complex human development to single letters. Those grades determine access to opportunities, which determine income, which determines where you can live and what choices you can make. We've built elaborate systems that require us to subordinate our natural sense of what matters to what can be measured.

This pattern emerged gradually:

First, we separated mind from body, observer from observed. What Descartes intended as a philosophical investigation became a deep cultural assumption: that the thinking mind is separate from and superior to what it observes. This made it easier to see nature - and eventually ourselves - as machines to be optimized rather than living wholes to be understood.

Then we narrowed cause and effect. Ancient thinkers like Aristotle saw multiple kinds of causation, including purpose and meaning. But the Scientific Revolution's success at predicting physical mechanics led us to prioritize only what could be measured and manipulated. The universe became a clockwork mechanism rather than a living reality.

Finally, we institutionalized this view. After World War II, traumatized by human irrationality and seeking stability, we built systems designed to control through measurement. GDP became the measure of national wellbeing. Standardized tests determined children's futures. Even social impact adopted business metrics, trying to quantify human flourishing.

The results surround us:
- Burnout rates in the social sector have risen 45% since 2019
- Youth anxiety and depression have doubled in the past decade
- Environmental indicators improve while ecosystems collapse
[Note: We should verify exact statistics]

Yet alternative ways of seeing persisted. Indigenous cultures maintained traditions that recognize quality and meaning directly. Contemplative practices preserved techniques for developing this perception. Even within modern institutions, people found ways to honor what couldn't be measured.

Consider the Zen tradition's approach to development: Masters can reliably recognize practitioners' states and prescribe appropriate practices, not through measurement but through direct perception refined over centuries. This isn't mystical - it's a rigorous science of quality, as precise in its way as physics.

Or consider how social media tries to quantify human connection through likes and shares while actual loneliness increases. The metrics improve while the meaning diminishes. We see this pattern everywhere: better measurements, worse outcomes.

Now we face challenges that can't be solved through measurement alone:
- Climate change requires sensing whole systems
- AI forces us to articulate what makes human experience meaningful
- Rising inequality shows the limits of purely economic metrics
- Mental health crises reveal our need for unquantifiable meaning

The good news is that we haven't lost this capacity entirely. Like a muscle weakened from disuse, our ability to perceive quality directly can be redeveloped. We don't need to reject measurement - we need to reintegrate it with our natural capacity for recognizing what matters.

This isn't about finding the neurological basis of consciousness or proving quality exists materially. As philosopher Ken Wilber notes, we can verify the reliability of qualitative perception through practice and experience, just as we verify scientific findings through experiment and observation.

The challenge now is to create conditions where this capacity can re-emerge - in ourselves, our organizations, and our societies. Not to replace quantitative thinking but to complement it with the quality-perceiving intelligence we've always had.

The question isn't whether this faculty exists - we use it every time we recognize beauty, truth, or meaning. The question is whether we'll remember how to trust it, develop it, and let it guide us alongside our capacity for measurement and analysis.

In the next section, we'll explore how to develop this capacity practically...

# How Worldviews Become Blindfolds

Imagine finding ancient sunglasses welded to your face - so long-worn you've forgotten they're there. The tint becomes your "normal," invisibly filtering everything you see. This is how foundational beliefs work: they don't just influence our thoughts, they shape what we can perceive in the first place.

Consider how deeply Darwinian thinking has shaped our view of human nature. Even after rejecting Social Darwinism's overt racism, we still unconsciously assume humans are fundamentally self-interested creatures needing control and management. This shows up everywhere: in how we design organizations, create incentives, measure impact.

But archaeologists like David Graeber tell a different story. The discovery of healed femurs from prehistoric humans reveals communities that cared for injured members who couldn't contribute materially for months or years. This isn't explainable through pure survival logic - it suggests humans have always been capable of acting from meaning and beauty rather than mere utility.

This isn't just academic history. These ancient examples reveal possibilities our current worldview renders invisible. Just as a fish doesn't know it's in water, we don't notice how thoroughly market logic and materialist assumptions shape what we imagine possible.

Some symptoms of our inherited blindness:
- Assuming people need external incentives to do good
- Treating meaning as a "soft" factor secondary to metrics
- Seeing nature as resource rather than relationship
- Believing control produces better outcomes than emergence

The challenge isn't just adopting new ideas but recognizing how deeply old ones shape our perception. It's not enough to intellectually accept that humans can act from meaning - we need to rediscover our capacity to perceive and act from it directly.

This is why simply adding new metrics or methods isn't enough. We need to understand how our inherited worldview became a perceptual prison, limiting what we can see and imagine. Only then can we begin removing these invisible filters and recovering our natural capacity for recognizing quality and meaning.

# The Beautiful Risk: What Sacrifice Reveals About Perception

When humans choose beauty over safety, meaning over survival, they reveal something profound about our nature. These moments aren't explicable through evolutionary logic or rational self-interest. They point to a different way of seeing that recognizes something more fundamental than physical survival.

Consider the archeological evidence: Early human communities caring for disabled members who couldn't contribute materially. Indigenous traditions of ceremonial giving that prioritize beauty and meaning over accumulation. These aren't aberrations - they reveal a capacity humans have always had to perceive and act from meaning directly.

We're moved to tears by stories of sacrifice for beauty: 
- A father running back into a burning building for his child
- A community protecting refugees despite threat to themselves
- Artists dedicating lives to work that might never be recognized
- Whistleblowers choosing truth over security

Why do these stories move us so deeply? Because they reveal what we already know but often forget: that there are things worth more than survival, that beauty and meaning aren't luxury add-ons to life but its very essence.

This has profound implications for social impact work:

Current Approach:
- Assumes people need incentives to do good
- Focuses on minimizing risk
- Measures what's countable over what matters
- Treats meaning as secondary to metrics

What Sacrifice Reveals:
- Humans naturally move toward beauty when they can see it
- Risk and sacrifice can be appropriate responses to meaning
- Our capacity to recognize quality is more reliable than metrics
- Beauty/meaning are primary motivators, not afterthoughts

This isn't about romanticizing sacrifice or ignoring practical needs. It's about recognizing that our capacity to perceive and act from meaning is fundamental to human nature. When we design systems assuming otherwise, we create the very self-interest we're trying to control.

The question for social impact isn't "How do we incentivize good behavior?" but "How do we create conditions where people can recognize and act from meaning naturally?" Not "How do we minimize risk?" but "How do we support beautiful risk-taking?"

This requires recovering our trust in the faculty that recognizes beauty and meaning directly. Not as emotional impulse but as a way of seeing more fundamental than rational analysis - the capacity that lets us know, without calculation, that saving a child from a burning building is right, that protecting refugees is beautiful, that truth matters more than comfort.

When we trust this perception, we don't need external incentives or control systems. Like the early humans who cared for injured members, we naturally move toward what we recognize as beautiful and meaningful, even at personal cost. This isn't irrational - it's a deeper rationality that recognizes meaning as fundamental to life as breath.

- Microfinance suicides
- Deaths from workplace burnout
- Rising youth mental health crises
- Lives crushed by bureaucratic systems

The Sacrifice for Meaning:
- Bouazizi's protest that sparked revolution
- Whistleblowers risking careers for truth
- Communities choosing dignity over safety
- Artists living in poverty for their work

- Aid systems that provide safety while crushing dignity
- Development metrics that improve while communities die
- Impact measurements that miss what makes life worth living

What if instead of designing systems to maximize safety and minimize risk, we designed them to maximize meaningful choice? What if instead of measuring success through metrics, we measured it by whether people can access the kind of meaning worth sacrificing for?

This isn't about romanticizing sacrifice or ignoring practical needs. It's about recognizing that humans need the possibility of meaningful sacrifice more fundamentally than they need safety. We need to know our lives could touch something worth dying for, even if we never face that choice.

When systems deny this - when they make safety and metrics primary - they create the conditions for despair. When they honor it - when they recognize meaning as fundamental - they create conditions where both safety and flourishing become possible.

The question for social impact isn't just "How do we help people survive?" but "How do we create conditions where life is worth living?" Not just "How do we measure impact?" but "How do we honor the meaning that makes metrics meaningful?"

On September 26, 1983, Lieutenant Colonel Stanislav Petrov faced a choice that would determine the fate of humanity. His early warning systems showed five nuclear missiles heading toward the Soviet Union. Protocol required immediate retaliation. Every metric, every system, every rational analysis said: Launch.

But something deeper than rationality made him hesitate. A quality he sensed but couldn't quantify told him something wasn't right. He chose to trust this perception over his instruments. We now know the warning system had malfunctioned - Petrov's choice to trust his deeper knowing quite literally saved humanity.

This capacity - to recognize quality and meaning directly - isn't new. It's our birthright, as ancient as humanity itself. Archaeological evidence shows early human communities investing enormous resources to care for injured members who couldn't contribute materially. Indigenous cultures worldwide developed sophisticated systems based on gift and reciprocity rather than pure calculation. In traditional villages, caring for neighbors wasn't charity - it was simply what it meant to be human.

What's new isn't the capacity itself but our systematic forgetting of it. We've created a world where "just the facts" trumps felt knowing, where "show me the numbers" dismisses direct perception of quality. We've built cities where we're more connected to strangers through social media than to our next-door neighbors, where artists starve while metrics thrive.

The Science of Seeing:
Research increasingly validates this forgotten faculty:
- Studies show humans naturally recognize patterns too complex to analyze rationally
- Neural research reveals we process meaning before conscious thought
- Social science demonstrates how gift economies created more stable societies than pure markets
- Anthropology shows cultures worldwide developed sophisticated practices for cultivating this perception

- Doctors who sense when standard protocols miss something crucial
- Teachers who recognize a student's potential beyond test scores
- Communities that maintain human connection despite systemic pressures
- Leaders who choose meaning over metrics even at personal cost

The cost of forgetting this faculty shows up everywhere:
- Mental health crises despite improving living standards
- Environmental collapse despite better measurements
- Social isolation despite more connectivity
- Work without meaning despite higher productivity

Yet this capacity remains, waiting to be recovered. Every time we recognize beauty without analysis, every time we know something is right without calculation, we touch this birthright.

The challenge isn't learning something new but remembering something fundamental:
- Not just measuring care but creating conditions where it emerges naturally
- Not just incentivizing cooperation but removing what blocks it
- Not just analyzing quality but recovering our capacity to recognize it directly

This has profound implications for how we design systems:
- What if we built organizations that trusted this knowing alongside metrics?
- What if we created cities that enabled rather than blocked natural human connection?
- What if we developed technologies that enhanced rather than replaced this perception?

We don't need to choose between rational analysis and direct perception of quality. Like stereoscopic vision, we need both to see depth. What we need is to remember this forgotten faculty, to trust it alongside our capacity for measurement and analysis.

The stakes couldn't be higher. Like Petrov, we face choices where metrics alone can't guide us. Climate change, artificial intelligence, social collapse - these challenges require both precise measurement and deep recognition of quality. We need our full human capacity for knowing what matters.

# From Metrics to Meaning: Reimagining How We Support Social Impact

Dear Dara and Munir,

I've been wrestling with something fundamental about our work at Bloom, and I think I'm finally finding language for it. It started becoming clear during our retreat in Dubai, watching our entrepreneurs share their stories. Seeing them come alive, watching tears flow as they shared their deep care for their communities - I realized we were witnessing something our metrics could never capture: the beauty of people fully aligned with their calling.

## What We're Missing

We've been operating with one eye closed. Like navigating solely by map without looking at the territory, we've prioritized metrics and frameworks over a more fundamental capacity: our ability to recognize quality and meaning directly. This isn't about emotions or intuition - it's about a perceptual faculty as real as sight or hearing, one that lets us recognize what's true, beautiful, and good.

I see this most clearly in how we've sometimes let measurement drive action. Remember when we pushed to get more people on the platform for feedback data? It felt wrong even as we did it, pulling us away from what entrepreneurs really needed. We knew better, but our metrics demanded it.

## What's Possible

But there's another way. Look at organizations like Buurtzorg in healthcare or Sounds True in publishing. They've built successful enterprises by trusting people's capacity to recognize and create quality. They've shown that when you create conditions for beauty to emerge rather than trying to force specific outcomes, both meaning and metrics improve naturally.

This isn't just philosophical - it has practical implications for how we work:

For Our Entrepreneurs:
- Deep self-knowledge leading to genuine confidence
- Connection to real mentors and wisdom
- Understanding their work as craft requiring mastery
- Natural attraction of resources through authenticity

For Our Team:
- Shift from monitoring to gardening
- Morning focus on understanding/seeing before metrics
- Deeper presence with teams
- More meaningful partner relationships

For Our Partners:
- Integration with their own sources of meaning
- Funding flowing to real value
- Shared recognition of quality

## A Path Forward

I believe we can test this approach through a simple experiment: offering coaching using our "come alive" methodology. Start free for a month, then charge as we prove value. We don't need external accreditation - our experience and reputation with entrepreneurs speaks for itself.

This isn't about abandoning metrics - it's about putting them in proper place. Like a gardener who measures growth but knows you can't force a flower to bloom, we need both eyes open: the eye that sees quality directly and the eye that tracks progress.

## Why This Matters

The entrepreneurs we serve don't need another accelerator pushing them toward predetermined metrics. They need:
- Space to recognize their own wisdom
- Support in developing their craft
- Community that sees their beauty
- Tools that serve their growth

When we provide this, I've watched them come alive. Not just "engaged" or "productive" - alive with purpose, clear in direction, magnetic to others. This is what creates lasting impact.

## Next Steps

I propose we:
1. Start small experiments with this approach
2. Document what we learn
3. Let evidence guide expansion
4. Build new frameworks based on real insight

This isn't a rejection of what we've built - it's an evolution toward what we've always meant to be: a space where social impact emerges naturally from people fully alive in their purpose.

What do you think? I'd love to discuss this more deeply.

With care and hope,
[Your name]

# From Metrics to Meaning: A New Vision for Social Impact

## Part I: Journey to Seeing with Both Eyes

The story of how I came to question our approach to social impact began in Dubai, watching entrepreneurs share their stories during our retreat. As tears flowed and hearts opened, I witnessed something our carefully designed metrics could never capture: the pure beauty of people fully aligned with their calling. In that moment, I realized we had been operating with one eye closed.

### The Blindness of Single Vision

Like many in social impact, I had internalized a worldview that prioritized measurement over meaning. We created dashboards, tracked KPIs, designed frameworks - all valuable tools, but ones that had somehow become primary rather than supportive. It was like navigating solely by map without looking at the territory, or trying to understand music purely through its sheet music without ever hearing it played.

This manifested most clearly in our platform metrics push. We needed data to improve, so we pushed entrepreneurs to engage online, even when it felt forced. Our metrics demanded it, but something deeper - a faculty I hadn't yet learned to trust - signaled this wasn't right.

### Breaking Through

The breakthrough came from recognizing that this sense wasn't just emotion or intuition - it was a legitimate perceptual faculty, as real as sight or hearing. This faculty lets us recognize quality directly, without needing to measure or analyze. It's what lets a master craftsperson know when something is right, what enables a teacher to recognize genuine understanding, what allows a community to sense authentic leadership.

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Single Vision: Metrics] -->|Leads to| B[Forced Outcomes]
    C[Double Vision: Metrics + Quality] -->|Enables| D[Natural Emergence]
    B -->|Creates| E[Resistance/Depletion]
    D -->|Creates| F[Alignment/Growth]
    G[Quality Recognition] -->|Informs| H[Better Metrics]
    H -->|Supports| G
```

### The Dubai Moment

This clarity crystallized watching our entrepreneurs share their work. Their stories weren't impressive because of impact numbers or scale metrics - though many had these. They moved us because we could recognize, directly and without analysis, the beauty of people aligned with genuine purpose. We saw what happens when someone connects with what they're meant to do and finds ways to serve that are uniquely theirs.

### Two Eyes Open

Now I understand: we need both eyes open. One eye for metrics and measurement - the map that helps us navigate and track progress. And one eye for direct quality recognition - the territory itself, the reality our maps try to represent. Like stereoscopic vision, it's the integration of both that gives depth and true understanding.

This isn't about abandoning metrics or structure. It's about putting them in proper place - as tools serving something more fundamental: our natural capacity to recognize and create quality, beauty, and meaning.
